canonical_explanation.text: India is a land of many festivals. People of different religions celebrate different festivals with great joy. Diwali is the festival of lights when we light diyas and burst crackers. Holi is the festival of colours when we play with colours and eat sweets. Eid is celebrated with prayers, new clothes, and seviyan. Christmas is celebrated with a Christmas tree, gifts, and cake. Harvest festivals like Onam, Pongal, Baisakhi, and Lohri are celebrated to thank God for good crops. We also celebrate national days like Republic Day on 26 January, Independence Day on 15 August, and Gandhi Jayanti on 2 October. Festivals teach us to love each other and live together happily.
rules: India has many festivals celebrated by people of different religions.
Diwali is the festival of lights and Holi is the festival of colours.
Eid, Christmas, Onam, Pongal, Baisakhi, and Lohri are important festivals.
Republic Day (26 January), Independence Day (15 August), and Gandhi Jayanti (2 October) are national days.
Festivals bring people together and teach us to share happiness.

questions.question_text: Diwali is called the festival of ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Diwali is called the festival of lights. People light diyas, candles, and decorate their homes with beautiful lights during Diwali.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Holi is the festival of colours, not Diwali. Diwali is the festival of lights when we light diyas and lamps to celebrate.

questions.question_text: During Holi, people play with ___.
questions.explanation_correct: During Holi, people play with colours. They put coloured powder and water on each other and have a lot of fun.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diyas are for Diwali, gifts are for Christmas. Holi is the festival of colours where people play with coloured powder and water.

questions.question_text: On which date do we celebrate Republic Day?
questions.explanation_correct: Republic Day is celebrated on 26 January. On this day, we remember when India got its Constitution, and a grand parade is held in Delhi.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 15 August is Independence Day, 2 October is Gandhi Jayanti, and 25 December is Christmas. Republic Day is on 26 January.

questions.question_text: Which festival is celebrated with a Christmas tree and gifts?
questions.explanation_correct: Christmas is celebrated with a Christmas tree and gifts. People decorate the tree with stars and lights and exchange presents on 25 December.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diwali has diyas, Holi has colours, and Eid has prayers and seviyan. Christmas is the festival with a Christmas tree, gifts, and cake.

questions.question_text: What do people light during Diwali?
questions.explanation_correct: People light candles and diyas during Diwali. The little oil lamps called diyas make homes and streets glow beautifully.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Colours are for Holi, kites are for Makar Sankranti, and drums are instruments. During Diwali, we light candles and diyas.

questions.question_text: Independence Day is celebrated on ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Independence Day is celebrated on 15 August. On this day in 1947, India became free from British rule. We hoist the national flag and sing the national anthem.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 26 January is Republic Day, 2 October is Gandhi Jayanti, and 14 November is Children's Day. Independence Day is on 15 August.

questions.question_text: Which sweet is special during Eid?
questions.explanation_correct: Seviyan (vermicelli) is the special sweet made during Eid. It is a delicious dessert made with thin noodles, milk, and sugar.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cake is for Christmas, and chocolate and ice cream are treats but not special to Eid. Seviyan is the traditional sweet prepared on Eid.

questions.question_text: Pongal, Baisakhi, Lohri, and Onam are all ___ festivals.
questions.explanation_correct: Pongal, Baisakhi, Lohri, and Onam are all harvest festivals. People celebrate these festivals to thank God for good crops and a good harvest.
questions.explanation_incorrect: These are not colour, light, or water festivals. They are harvest festivals celebrated in different parts of India when crops are ready.

questions.question_text: Gandhi Jayanti is celebrated on ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Gandhi Jayanti is celebrated on 2 October. This is the birthday of Mahatma Gandhi, the Father of the Nation, who helped India become free.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 26 January is Republic Day, 15 August is Independence Day, and 25 December is Christmas. Gandhi Jayanti is on 2 October.

questions.question_text: What do people make on the floor during Diwali?
questions.explanation_correct: People make rangoli on the floor during Diwali. Rangoli is a beautiful design made with coloured powder at the entrance of homes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Snowmen, sand castles, and paper planes are not made during Diwali. Rangoli is the colourful floor design made to welcome guests during Diwali.

questions.question_text: During Eid, children receive money from elders. This money is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: The money children receive from elders during Eid is called Eidi. It is a special gift that makes children very happy during the festival.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gift cards, pocket money, and prizes are different things. Eidi is the special money that elders give to children during the festival of Eid.

questions.question_text: Which festival is celebrated on 25 December?
questions.explanation_correct: Christmas is celebrated on 25 December. It is the birthday of Jesus Christ and is celebrated with joy, gifts, and cake.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diwali, Eid, and Holi are celebrated on different dates each year. Christmas is always on 25 December.

questions.question_text: Onam is a harvest festival celebrated in ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Onam is celebrated in Kerala. It is a grand harvest festival where people make flower carpets (pookalam), eat a big feast, and have boat races.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Baisakhi is in Punjab, Pongal is in Tamil Nadu. Onam is the famous harvest festival of Kerala.

questions.question_text: What do we hoist on Independence Day and Republic Day?
questions.explanation_correct: We hoist the national flag on Independence Day and Republic Day. Our flag, the tiranga, is hoisted with pride and we sing the national anthem.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Kites, balloons, and banners are not hoisted on national days. The national flag (tiranga) is hoisted with respect on these important days.

questions.question_text: Lohri is celebrated mainly in ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Lohri is celebrated mainly in Punjab. People light a big bonfire, sing songs, dance, and eat peanuts, popcorn, and rewri (sweet).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Onam is in Kerala, Pongal is in Tamil Nadu. Lohri is the festival of Punjab celebrated with bonfire, songs, and dance.

questions.question_text: During festivals, people wear ___.
questions.explanation_correct: During festivals, people wear new clothes. Wearing new clothes is a happy tradition that makes festivals more special and joyful.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Old clothes, school uniforms, and sports clothes are not worn during festivals. People buy and wear new, beautiful clothes to celebrate.

questions.question_text: Pongal is a harvest festival celebrated in ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Pongal is celebrated in Tamil Nadu. During Pongal, people cook sweet rice in milk (also called pongal) and thank the Sun and cows.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Onam is in Kerala and Baisakhi is in Punjab. Pongal is the harvest festival of Tamil Nadu.

questions.question_text: Anita celebrates Diwali and her friend Sara celebrates Eid. They share sweets with each other. What does this show?

options.text: They do not like each other
People of different religions can be friends and share happiness

questions.explanation_correct: Sharing sweets shows that people of different religions can be friends and share happiness. India is beautiful because different people celebrate together.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sharing sweets during festivals is a sign of love and friendship. All festivals are important, and people of different religions can and should be friends.

questions.question_text: Baisakhi is celebrated in Punjab. What are people thankful for during this festival?
questions.explanation_correct: During Baisakhi, people are thankful for a good harvest of crops. Farmers celebrate because their hard work has given them plenty of wheat and other grains.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Baisakhi is not about school, phones, or games. It is a harvest festival where farmers thank God for a good crop of wheat.

questions.question_text: Why do we celebrate Independence Day?

options.text: Because we get a holiday from school
Because India became free from British rule on this day
Because it is a festival of lights

questions.explanation_correct: We celebrate Independence Day because India became free from British rule on 15 August 1947. It is a very proud day for all Indians.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Independence Day is not about school holidays, lights, or birthdays. We celebrate because our country became free on 15 August 1947.

questions.question_text: During Holi, Raj does not want to play with colours because he has new clothes. His mother says he can wear old clothes. Now Raj ___.

options.text: Should stay at home and cry
Can wear old clothes and enjoy playing Holi
Should throw colours at people who do not want to play

questions.explanation_correct: Raj can wear old clothes and enjoy playing Holi. Wearing old clothes during Holi is a smart idea so that new clothes do not get spoiled by colours.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Raj does not need to stay home or be angry. By wearing old clothes, he can happily play Holi without worrying about spoiling his new clothes.

questions.question_text: Your class has children who celebrate different festivals. Why is this a good thing?

options.text: It is not a good thing
We can learn about different cultures and traditions
We should only celebrate our own festival

questions.explanation_correct: Having children from different backgrounds is wonderful because we can learn about different cultures, traditions, and festivals. It makes our class more interesting!
questions.explanation_incorrect: All festivals and cultures are important. Learning about different traditions helps us understand and respect each other better.

questions.question_text: Arjun's family celebrates Diwali. His neighbour invites him for Christmas dinner. What should Arjun do?

options.text: Say no because it is not his festival
Go happily and enjoy the celebration

questions.explanation_correct: Arjun should go happily and enjoy the celebration. Celebrating each other's festivals brings people closer and shows love and respect.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Refusing, getting angry, or ignoring is not kind. In India, we celebrate each other's festivals with joy. This is what unity in diversity means.

questions.question_text: Why do we share sweets and gifts during festivals?

options.text: To show love and spread happiness

questions.explanation_correct: We share sweets and gifts during festivals to show love and spread happiness. It makes our friends, family, and neighbours feel special and cared for.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sharing is not forced, not about cost, and not about showing off. We share sweets and gifts to express love and bring joy to others.

questions.question_text: On Republic Day, your school has a flag hoisting ceremony. What should you do during the national anthem?
questions.explanation_correct: During the national anthem, we should stand straight and show respect. The national anthem is a symbol of our country's pride and honour.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Talking, sitting, or running during the national anthem is disrespectful. We must always stand at attention and sing along respectfully.

questions.question_text: Festivals in India are celebrated by people of ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Festivals in India are celebrated by people of many different religions. Hindus, Muslims, Christians, Sikhs, and others all have their own beautiful festivals.
questions.explanation_incorrect: India has many religions, and each has special festivals. Festivals are enjoyed by everyone - children and grown-ups of all religions.

questions.question_text: Who is Santa Claus associated with?
questions.explanation_correct: Santa Claus is associated with Christmas. Santa is a jolly old man in red clothes who brings gifts for children on Christmas Eve.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Santa Claus is not part of Diwali, Holi, or Eid. He is a beloved figure of Christmas who brings presents for children.

questions.question_text: Why should we NOT burst loud crackers during Diwali?

options.text: Because they cause noise and air pollution and scare animals

questions.explanation_correct: We should not burst loud crackers because they cause noise and air pollution. They also scare animals and can hurt people. We can enjoy Diwali with diyas, rangoli, and sweets instead.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The problem with loud crackers is not about cost or looks. They pollute the air, make too much noise, scare animals, and can be dangerous.

questions.question_text: Which of these is a national day, NOT a religious festival?
questions.explanation_correct: Republic Day is a national day, not a religious festival. It is celebrated by all Indians together regardless of religion, on 26 January.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diwali, Eid, and Christmas are religious festivals. Republic Day is a national day celebrated by all citizens of India.

questions.question_text: Match the festival with the correct celebration: Holi â€” ___.

options.text: Decorating a tree and giving gifts
Playing with colours and eating gujiya
Lighting a bonfire and eating peanuts

questions.explanation_correct: Holi is celebrated by playing with colours and eating gujiya (a sweet). Lighting diyas is for Diwali, decorating a tree is for Christmas, and bonfire is for Lohri.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diyas are for Diwali, tree and gifts are for Christmas, bonfire and peanuts are for Lohri. Holi is about playing with colours and eating gujiya.

questions.question_text: India is called a land of festivals because ___.

options.text: People of many religions celebrate many different festivals
India does not have any festivals

questions.explanation_correct: India is called a land of festivals because people of many religions live here and celebrate many different festivals throughout the year.
questions.explanation_incorrect: India has not one but many festivals. People of different religions celebrate their own festivals, making India a colourful and joyful country.

questions.question_text: Which pair of festivals are BOTH harvest festivals?
questions.explanation_correct: Pongal and Baisakhi are both harvest festivals. Pongal is celebrated in Tamil Nadu and Baisakhi in Punjab, both thanking God for good crops.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Diwali is a festival of lights, Christmas is a Christian festival, Holi is a festival of colours, and Republic Day and Gandhi Jayanti are national days. Pongal and Baisakhi are harvest festivals.

questions.question_text: What is the most important lesson that festivals teach us?

options.text: To love, share, and live together happily

questions.explanation_correct: The most important lesson of festivals is to love, share, and live together happily. Festivals bring families and communities closer to each other.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While sweets and new things are part of festivals, the real meaning is about love, sharing, and togetherness.

questions.question_text: Which national day is the birthday of Mahatma Gandhi?
questions.explanation_correct: Gandhi Jayanti, celebrated on 2 October, is the birthday of Mahatma Gandhi. He is called the Father of the Nation and taught us about truth and non-violence.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Republic Day is about our Constitution, Independence Day is about freedom from British rule, and Children's Day is Nehru's birthday. Gandhi Jayanti celebrates Mahatma Gandhi's birthday.

questions.question_text: During which festival do people in Punjab light a bonfire, sing, and dance?
questions.explanation_correct: During Lohri, people in Punjab light a big bonfire, sing traditional songs, dance the Bhangra, and eat peanuts, popcorn, and rewri.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Onam is in Kerala, Pongal is in Tamil Nadu, and Christmas is celebrated differently. Lohri is the Punjab festival with bonfire, songs, and dance.

questions.question_text: Meena's family celebrates Diwali. She wants to celebrate in a way that is safe for the environment. What should she do?

options.text: Light diyas and make rangoli instead of bursting crackers

questions.explanation_correct: Meena should light diyas and make rangoli instead of bursting crackers. This way she can enjoy Diwali without polluting the air or causing noise.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Loud crackers pollute the environment. Not celebrating is extreme. Lighting diyas and making rangoli is a beautiful, eco-friendly way to celebrate Diwali.

questions.question_text: A parade is held in New Delhi on Republic Day. What can you see in the parade?

options.text: Soldiers marching, tanks, and cultural performances

questions.explanation_correct: On Republic Day, a grand parade in New Delhi shows soldiers marching, tanks, weapons, and beautiful cultural performances from different states of India.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rangoli is for Diwali, Santa is for Christmas, and colours are for Holi. The Republic Day parade features the military and cultural displays.

questions.question_text: Which of these is TRUE about festivals in India?

options.text: Different religions have different festivals and all are important

questions.explanation_correct: Different religions have different festivals and all are important. Every festival teaches us about love, sharing, and being together.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Many religions have festivals, not just one. Festivals are for everyone and they bring joy and togetherness, which is never a waste of time.

questions.question_text: Your school is celebrating all festivals together. Why is this a good idea?

options.text: So children learn about and respect all cultures

questions.explanation_correct: Celebrating all festivals in school helps children learn about and respect all cultures and religions. It teaches unity and togetherness.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The real purpose is not holidays or sweets. When schools celebrate all festivals, children learn to appreciate diversity and respect each other.

questions.question_text: Kiran's family does not celebrate Eid, but her friend Zara invited her to an Eid party. Kiran went and had a wonderful time. What did Kiran learn?

options.text: Eid is not a good festival
We can enjoy and learn from other people's festivals too
She should not go next time
Only her own festival is the best

questions.explanation_correct: Kiran learned that we can enjoy and learn from other people's festivals too. Celebrating together builds friendship and understanding between people.
questions.explanation_incorrect: All festivals are beautiful. Kiran learned something wonderful - that celebrating with friends from different backgrounds is fun and enriching.

questions.question_text: Diwali is the festival of colours.
questions.explanation_correct: Diwali is not the festival of colours. Diwali is the festival of lights. Holi is the festival of colours.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is false. Diwali is the festival of lights, not colours. We light diyas and candles during Diwali. Holi is the festival of colours.

questions.question_text: Republic Day is celebrated on 26 January.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes, Republic Day is celebrated on 26 January every year. A grand parade is held in New Delhi on this day.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is true. Republic Day is indeed celebrated on 26 January, the day India's Constitution came into effect.

questions.question_text: Christmas is celebrated by decorating a Christmas tree and exchanging gifts.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes, during Christmas people decorate a Christmas tree with lights and stars, and exchange gifts with family and friends.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is true. Decorating the Christmas tree and exchanging gifts are popular traditions of Christmas, celebrated on 25 December.

questions.question_text: Pongal is a harvest festival of Punjab.
questions.explanation_correct: Pongal is not a festival of Punjab. Pongal is a harvest festival of Tamil Nadu. The harvest festival of Punjab is Baisakhi or Lohri.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is false. Pongal belongs to Tamil Nadu, not Punjab. Baisakhi and Lohri are the harvest festivals of Punjab.

questions.question_text: Gandhi Jayanti is celebrated on 2 October.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes, Gandhi Jayanti is celebrated on 2 October, the birthday of Mahatma Gandhi, the Father of the Nation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is true. 2 October is the birthday of Mahatma Gandhi, and we celebrate it as Gandhi Jayanti every year.

questions.question_text: Festivals teach us to share happiness and live together peacefully.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes, festivals teach us to share happiness, be kind to others, and live together peacefully. They bring families and communities closer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is true. The true meaning of any festival is spreading joy, sharing with others, and building love and togetherness.

questions.question_text: Only one religion celebrates festivals in India.
questions.explanation_correct: This is not true. Many religions celebrate festivals in India - Hindus celebrate Diwali and Holi, Muslims celebrate Eid, Christians celebrate Christmas, Sikhs celebrate Baisakhi, and many more.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is false. India has people of many religions, and each religion has its own special festivals. This is what makes India so colourful.

questions.question_text: During Holi, we should put colours on someone who does not want to play.
questions.explanation_correct: We should not put colours on someone who does not want to play. We should respect everyone's choice. We should only play Holi with people who want to play.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is false. We must always respect others' wishes. If someone does not want to play Holi, we should not force them.

questions.question_text: Independence Day and Republic Day are both national days of India.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes, both Independence Day (15 August) and Republic Day (26 January) are national days of India. All Indians celebrate them together.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is true. Independence Day marks India's freedom, and Republic Day marks the start of our Constitution. Both are important national days.

questions.question_text: Rangoli is a colourful pattern made on the floor, usually during Diwali.
questions.explanation_correct: Yes, rangoli is a colourful pattern made on the floor using coloured powders, flower petals, or rice. It is made to welcome guests, especially during Diwali.
questions.explanation_incorrect: This is true. Rangoli is a beautiful tradition where colourful designs are drawn on the floor, especially during Diwali, to make homes look festive.
